results.title: In the King of Prussia
results.creator_credit: Turin Film Corporation and Emile de Antonio
results.brief_description: In September 1980, eight Catholic pacifists known as the Plowshare 8 entered the G. E. plant known as ‘King of Prussia’. They damaged two nuclear missile nose-cones and poured blood on weapon parts. By condensing 1300 pages of trial transcripts into a 70-page film script a courtroom drama has been staged. The defendants play themselves. Cast: The Plowshares 8, Martin Sheen, Jackson Browne.

results.title: In the jaws of death = Jiao suo xia de jiao yi
results.creator_credit: Shanghai Film Studio and Song Chong
results.brief_description:
This film is based on the real events surrounding the theft of hundreds of priceless ancient artifacts and the ensuing sting operation to recover them before they are sold off out of the country and dispersed across the globe.

During the 1980s there was a haze of activity taking place between the Hong Kong triads and the mainland gangs, who had the goods but wanted in on the lavish wealth enjoyed by those across the border. The triads were at war, with the Gold and Black gangs undercutting each other every chance they get.

Though there is a distinct lack of choreographic finesse when it comes to martial arts battles between gangs and cops, the plot is one mainly of secret deals, which gradually evolve from the stereotypical exchanging of passwords like “There’s a dragon on the sea”, and “There’s a tiger in the mountain”, to highly complex double- and triple-dealings between the gangs and customs officials.

The Gold and Black gangs have both gotten wind of this unprecedented collection of stolen antiques and immediately smell a lucrative business opportunity. The big bosses send their underlings to engage the sellers in a secret deal to have the goods transported to Hong Kong. However it is not long before they soon realise that the other gang has made steps to undercut their bid.

This results in an ice-cold bidding war, with all three sides displaying their underground cunning and thrill for the life of crime. The only thing these people share is a lack of compulsion against lying, thieving and tricking one another to get to the top.

The plot is intricately woven and well executed. However, it does not present itself as a film that has aged well, and the ending is unsurprisingly bland, with everything turning out alright in the end, thanks to the almost superhumanly intelligent Chinese authorities.
(2 stars - James Donald; June 8, 2011)

results.title: In the heat of the night
results.creator_credit: Mirisch Corporation, Walter Mirisch and Norman Jewison
results.brief_description: Set in the deep South at the height of the early 60’s racial tension, this superbly crafted murder mystery deserved all five of its Academy Awards. Best actor winner Rod Steiger gives a definitive performance as a small town, red-neck sheriff who finds himself in an uneasy alliance with a black homicide detective from Philadelphia, strikingly portrayed by Sidney Poitier. In the course of investigating the crime, the two strong-willed men must reconcile their inherent prejudice towards each other. The final result is justice and an unlikely but touching mutual respect. Supporting performances by Warren Oates and Lee Grant, an evocative score by Quincy Jones and Haskell Wexler’s vivid cinematography combine to create the stifling aura of a hot summer evening in the South. The Oscar winning script by Stirling Silliphant is based on a novel by John Ball.

results.title: In the gutter, no way?
results.creator_credit: Australia. Special Broadcasting Service and Rhoda Roberts
results.brief_description: Bobby McLeod, Marlene Cummins and Reg King recount their experiences of growing up as Aborigines in a white society that didn’t recognise their history or respect their rights. As recovering alcoholics, they discuss the factors that enabled them to overcome their alcoholism, when, as stigmatised outcasts in their own land, there was no place to turn to.

results.title: In the form of clay
results.creator_credit: Gustavsbergs Fabriker, Tor Flyckt, Olle Hallberg and Stig Lasseby
results.brief_description: The procelain industry of Gustavsberg in Sweden is shown in all its aspects from the processing of the raw clay to the finished product; moulding and forming, the application of color and design by hand and machine followed by the glazing and firing. Features the designs of three of Sweden’s foremost craftsmen.

results.title: In the footsteps of the pharaohs
results.creator_credit: Grainger Television Australia and Greg Grainger
results.brief_description: Producer and presenter Greg Grainger embarks on a journey into the ancient civilization of Egypt’s past, as well as the vibrancy of modern Egypt. He begins his journey at Abu Simbel near the Sudanese border, sails across dams in Aswan, along the river Nile to Luxor, and in Cairo explores new excavations around the pyramids. Along the way he encounters boatmen, bellydancers, feasts, markets, bazaars, and wedding festivities. The sights and sounds are a lasting legacy of an amazing ancient culture.

results.title: In the footsteps of Alexander the Great
results.brief_description: Michael Wood travels from Europe to India on an epic 20,000 mile journey in search of the truth behind one of history’s greatest stories. Travelling by bus, steam train, ancient sail boat and camel train, Michael follows the tracks of Alexander the Great into the heart of Asia. Along the route through Egypt, the Khyber Pass, Pakistan’s Indus River and the dreaded Makran Desert, the history and myths of this great figure are explored. Scholars, Turkish bards, Uzbek herders and those who claim descent from Alexander’s army all enlighten a fantastic journey and tell the story of a man who left an indelible mark on the history of the world. A teacher’s guide and additional educational resources can be downloaded from the PBS web site: http://pbs.bilkent.edu.tr/mpt/alexander/index.html (Accessed 15/3/2000)
